intro: Acanthopanax sessiliflorus, commonly known as the sessile-flowered arrowhead, is a climbing shrub native to East Asia. It belongs to the family Araliaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbels, followed by red berries that are toxic to humans. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in mountainous regions. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal uses, it is sometimes cultivated in horticulture.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthopanax sessiliflorus is primarily native to eastern Asia, including regions such as China, Korea, and Japan. It is commonly found in temperate forests and mountainous areas, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. This plant is particularly associated with the Korean Peninsula and parts of southern China, where it grows in shaded undergrowth. It is often found in regions with a humid climate and is adapted to the cool, forested environments of these areas. Its native range extends into parts of Russia and the Himalayas, where it occupies similar ecological niches.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthopanax sessiliflorus was mainly introduced to regions where it can thrive in temperate climates with well-drained soils. It is commonly found in forested areas, often growing as an understory plant. The distribution includes parts of East Asia, such as China, Korea, and Japan. It has been introduced to other parts of the world for ornamental purposes due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. However, its spread is limited by specific environmental requirements and local ecological conditions.
